page.title: 15NAMES OF COPSES AND WOODS
page.content: The name of each wood tells you about its history. The word 'field' indicates areas converted from arable: 'furzefield' or 'rough' suggests areas which were formerly common or scrub. Some names refer to farmer owners or tenants - Buckman, Oliver, Groom, Butler, Braxby, Reed. Fox Rough is named after a pub. Poling Furzefields was a detached part of Poling parish until 1878. Parham Fields is presumably connected with the Bysshopp family who lived at Parham Park and owned much land in Angmering. Hammerpot Copse and Charbe Copse are named from these hamlets. Wepham Ball is perhaps named from a Boundary Mound known as a ball in old English. These mounds were common in areas without natural stone. Gibbet Place is where the body of Jack Upperton, a highwayman, was hung in chains in 1771
